messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 18, 2017 - January 24, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-26T15:35:09Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-01-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170126-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-01-18T15:00Z to 2017-01-19T03:00Z.  This small enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-01-18.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2017-01-19.  

The IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments at STEREO A detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-01-20.  The solar wind speed reached values >700 km/s on 2017-01-22.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-01-21T05:00Z     ~531            C               129/16                31                          SOHO                              
2017-01-24T17:00Z     ~539            C               100/10                22                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-01-31T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the next reporting period.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be enhanced for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-01-27.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 11, 2017 - January 17, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-18T19:24:15Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-01-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170118-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-01-12T16:24Z     ~580            C               -90/1                 36                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2017-01-14T05:36Z     ~628            C              -155/10                10                          SOHO                              
2017-01-17T21:49Z     ~723            C               160/11                11                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-01-24T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low.  The active regions visible on the solar disk appear to have low magnetic complexity.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate to high for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2017-01-18.  Solar wind speeds of 600-700 km/s are expected.  

## Notes:

O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 04, 2017 - January 10, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-11T20:20:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-04T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-01-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170111-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

A coronal hole high speed stream was detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2017-01-07.  Solar wind speed reached values close to 700 km/s on 2017-01-08.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-01-06T13:50Z, and remained elevated crossing the threshold several times during the reporting period.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-01-03 (see notifications 20170106-AL-001, 20170106-AL-002, 20170108-AL-001, and 20170110-AL-001).  Solar wind speed reached values of >700 km/s on 2017-01-05.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-01-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming reporting period.  The active regions in the field view of SDO (Earth-facing solar disk) and STEREO A (farside of the sun) are sparse and relatively simple in complexity.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be become slightly elevated by 2017-01-12 due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-10T13:29:11Z
## Message ID: 20170110-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above and around 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-01-06T13:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-01-03T07:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-01-06T13:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 28, 2016 - January 03, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-04T23:31:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-01-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170104-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were two C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with a Kp index of (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The geomagnetic Kp index reached level 4 (below minor) during the synoptic period 2017-01-01T00:00Z to 2017-01-01T03:00Z. This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with a high speed stream arriving at the DSCOVR spacecraft at L1 around 2016-12-31. The maximum value of solar wind speed reached ~580 km/s on 2017-01-01.  The solar wind decreased before increasing again to ~500 km/s on 2017-01-03 and 2017-01-04.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-12-31T01:39Z     ~558            C              -104/34                15                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2017-01-03T03:12Z     ~645            C              -105/-10               20                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-01-10T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week.  The current solar wind high speed stream is expected to reach speeds of up to ~700 km/s on 2017-01-06 and could lead to minor/moderate geomagnetic activity. The active regions in the field view of SDO (Earth-facing solar disk) and STEREO A (farside of the sun) are sparse and relatively simple in complexity. The likelihood of solar eruptions is low. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, Mars, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-01-03T23:31:56Z
## Message ID: 20170103-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-01-03T03:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~645 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -105/-10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-01-03T03:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer, Mars (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2017-01-06T07:31Z, Mars at 2017-01-07T06:00Z, and STEREO A at 2017-01-06T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2017-01-03T03:12:00-CME-001):
